title: Ghosn Escape-Plot Defendants Argue They Didn't Commit Crime
summary: Lawyers for former Green Beret and his son focus on quirk in Japanese law. A former Green Beret wanted by Japan for his alleged role in the escape of auto titan Carlos Ghosn didn't commit a crime in Japan and shouldn't be extradited there, his lawyers argued in a legal filing Monday.

title: S&P 500 Rebounds to Close in Positive Territory for the Year
summary: Nasdaq Composite reaches its first record close in nearly four months. The S&P 500 turned positive for the year on Monday, erasing a plunge that had taken the stock index down more than 30% by March, a testament to investors' optimism about the economic recovery.

title: Macy's Raises $4.5 Billion, Funding Its Operations Through Fiscal 2021
summary: The retailer also plans to use the funds for inventory and to pay off debt. Struggling department store chain Macy's Inc. has secured about $4.5 billion in financing to help it fund its operations and new inventory, resolve outstanding payments and repay debt coming due in fiscal 2020 and fiscal 2021.

title: Defund Police, Watch Crime Return
summary: Offenses in some cities were rising before the pandemic.. One feature of our current politics is how quickly bad events trigger a rush to bad policies. So it is that the response to the killing of George Floyd has sprinted past police reform to "defund the police." Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti wants to redirect $150 million from public safety to social programs, and Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey was hooted from a protest on the weekend because he admitted he didn't want to defund the police. City Council members now pledge to dismantle the force whether he wants to or not.

title: For 3-D-Printing Hobbyists, Coronavirus Pandemic Is a Call to Serve
summary: Home 3-D output has shifted from novelty items to personal protective equipment for health-care workers and others on the front lines. Practically overnight, 3-D-printing enthusiasts have remolded their home-based hobby into an emergency production line for scarce personal protective equipment for front-line workers.

title: The Shutdown Budget
summary: The federal deficit for the fiscal year reaches $1.9 trillion.. There's nothing like a government-ordered economic shutdown to blow a hole in government finances. That was the bad if entirely expected news on Monday when the Congressional Budget Office released its monthly budget review for May.

title: Cancel Culture Journalism
summary: Two liberal editors fall for violations against progressive orthodoxy.. The purge of senior editors at progressive newspapers this weekend is no cause for cheering. Their resignations are another milestone in the march of identity politics and cancel culture through our liberal institutions, and American journalism and democracy will be worse for it.

title: New Treatments for a Common Cause of Blindness Are On the Way
summary: Doctors may soon have a new array of tools to treat and prevent this age-related vision loss. Scientists may be just a few years away from delivering new treatments for age-related macular degeneration (AMD), the leading cause of irreversible vision loss in people more than 50 years old.

title: Pennsylvania's Mail-In Primary Pains
summary: Ballots are still being counted after riots and confusion.. Pennsylvania last year passed legislation to allow mail-in voting, and the June 2 primaries were the first test of this new system. Nearly a week later, voters still don't know the victors for some races, and don't be surprised if some candidates challenge the results in court. Behold the messiness of mail-in voting-and brace for November.

title: How to Make Offices More Healthful-and Less Stressful
summary: Employers need to create offices that workers will feel safe to come back to. More employers are trying to create an office that workers will actually want to come back to as pandemic-related lockdowns ease across the country.

title: New Jersey Officials Release Video of State Trooper Shooting Black Man
summary: Maurice Gordon Jr. was shot and killed on May 23 after being pulled over on Garden State Parkway. New Jersey law-enforcement officials released video footage Monday showing a state trooper shooting and killing a black man during a traffic stop last month.

title: The Unequal American City
summary: The hollowing out of the middle class is largely a metropolitan phenomenon, but no one fix will help all.. Most rural communities, small towns and modest-sized metro areas have seen dramatically lower rates of Covid-19 infection than big urban areas, especially the super-dense New York City region. This has led to predictable upset and pushback when state officials treated less populated regions the same as more crowded ones. As one county commissioner in Oregon told NPR, "We have no vile threat that it's going to be expanding around here, so why in God's name are you still holding us to restrictions?"

title: Are Social Workers the Answer?
summary: Not if the goal of 'abolishing the police' is to stop the authorities from harassing people for minor missteps.. 'Abolish the Police," protesters chant. What does that mean? One widely tweeted answer: "Almost every role in our community a police officer fills would be better handled by a social worker." Yet consider an area in which social workers already tend to be the ones who enforce the law. Child-protection agencies routinely send social workers to respond to reports of abuse or neglect.

title: Coronavirus Made Me Give Up Cash
summary: I've always had a wad of bills in my pocket-but now I'm careful.. For seven weeks I kept the Ziploc bag under a bench in our living room. I was in no rush to extract its suspicious contents, but I didn't want to dump it. Why throw out $15 if it isn't going to kill you?

title: Enemies See a Weak and Divided U.S.
summary: But they're wrong. The protests showed some of America's enduring strengths.. As the White House fumbles with its response to the country's most disruptive mass movement since the Vietnam War and U.S. society reflects on the agonizing problems of race relations, many overseas observers will interpret these events as a further sign of American decline. They likely expect an introspective and divided U.S. to withdraw from world affairs. This is a mistake.

title: The Mayhem Is the Message
summary: If the aim of violence is to expose the racism of America, the worse the better.. For Americans of goodwill, the chaos and criminality transpiring in the name of George Floyd are absolutely baffling.

title: 'Billion Dollar Burger' Review: Wherefrom the Beef?
summary: Who will be ﬁrst to market with a 'clean meat' product cultured in a lab from animal cells? And will chefs and consumers accept it?. It seemed like regal treatment for five ounces of uncooked hamburger. In 2013, on a brightly lit London stage with cameras trained on him, Mark Post, a researcher at Maastricht University in the Netherlands, ceremoniously lifted a silver cloche, unveiling a pinkish patty. British chef Richard McGeown did the honors of searing the burger, and thereby made history.

title: Protesters Gain Backing of Some Lawmakers as Mourners View Floyd's Body
summary: House Democrats propose police overhaul; judge sets bail for Derek Chauvin. HOUSTON-Lines of hundreds of mourners moved quickly through the Fountain of Praise church where George Floyd rested in a casket lined in blue.

title: Former Treasury Officials Positioned to Shape Fintech From Private Sector
summary: A spate of fintech hires suggests that new cryptocurrency and other financial technology regulations could be shaped as much by the private sector as by federal agencies themselves. Financial technology companies are snapping up former government officials as they seek to navigate the still-developing patchwork of regulations governing cryptocurrency and other financial technology.

title: A Look Inside New York's Grand Reopening
summary: Resume Subscription. The reopening of New York-the city that contributes the most to the gross domestic product-is being carefully watched by public health officials and economists across the country. The plan is to reopen in phases, starting this week with construction, agriculture, manufacturing and wholesale trade. Retail stores can also offer curbside and in-store pickup. Above, work stirs on a construction site Monday.

title: New York City Begins Reopening; Cases Surge in India
summary: Vermont contends with cluster; concerns rise that George Floyd demonstrations will spur jump in cases. • The U.S. coronavirus death toll passed 110,000 while reported cases topped 1.9 million, according to data compiled by Johns Hopkins University. Cases world-wide topped seven million, and deaths stood at more than 405,000. Experts say official totals likely understate the extent of the pandemic, in part because of differing testing and reporting standards.

title: 'Cold War' Isn't Helpful in China Relations
summary: I suspect‎ that Rep. Mike Gallagher and I would agree on much of U.S. policy toward China, but I urge him to reconsider the "cold war" label.. I suspect‎that Rep. Mike Gallagher and I would agree on much of U.S. policy toward China, but I urge him to reconsider the "cold war" label ("Yes, America Is in a Cold War With China," op-ed, June 8). First, the U.S. built and relied on alliances in the Cold War; today, America is undermining its alliances, and we will push partners further away with cold-war rhetoric. Second, the "containment" doctrine framed U.S. Cold War policies; America cannot contain China, and our allies will resist that mistake. Third, Rep. Gallagher correctly recognizes the threat of McCarthyite excess; at a time of internal division, cold-war rhetoric is already leading to harassment of Asian-Americans. Fourth, the Soviet Union advanced communist ideology around the world and directed communist parties and insurrection; China's communism is based on Han chauvinism, it pursues national interests regardless of political regime and, in fact, Beijing wants to avoid (recalling the 1960s) hostility toward overseas Chinese.

title: PG&E Chases Hot Debt Markets Ahead of Bankruptcy Plan Approval
summary: Favorable conditions have the California utility looking to issue bonds for exit financing while chapter 11 courtroom arguments continue. PG&E Corp. wants authority to tap hot corporate debt markets for about $11 billion in financing even as courtroom arguments continue about the company's bankruptcy exit plan.

title: New York Needs Real Reform, Not a Data Tax
summary: New York's budget problems stem not from a lack of revenue but from outsize, unsustainable spending.. Regarding Eric Adams and Andrew Gounardes's "A Tax on Data Could Fix New York's Budget" (op-ed, June 2): I find it amusing and somewhat ironic that two New York politicians are now proposing to tax tech companies for access to personal consumer data for marketing purposes. Was it just a year ago that New York City decided to pass on an Amazon HQ facility that would have employed 25,000, generating billions of dollars annually, most of it subject to taxation to the benefit of New York City and state's coffers?

title: Floyd's Death: Time to Discuss Racial Bias
summary: When I questioned the trooper why I was stopped, he told me "because you are a young black male in a sports car.". The tragic death of George Floyd has triggered memories and emotions ("Fresh Charges Brought in Floyd Killing," Page One, June 4). As a pre-med student at Columbia University, I had guns pulled on me by police officers because they thought I was a chain snatcher. As a young orthopedic surgeon traveling to fellowship training in Philadelphia, I was stopped by a New Jersey state trooper. I was singled out from a number of cars all traveling 65 mph on the New Jersey Turnpike. When I questioned the trooper why I was stopped, he told me "because you are a young black male in a sports car." That was 25 years ago. It didn't have a name then, but it since has been called DWB (driving while black). Over the years, there were countless other episodes.

title: Where Was the GOP When the Lax PPP Bill Was Written?
summary: The Republicans stood by as the Democrats subsidized unemployment with a $600 bonus, ensuring a slower and more expensive recovery.. In "How to Fix the Paycheck Protection Program" (op-ed, June 1), Sen. Ron Johnson bemoans the problems of the PPP, yet takes no responsibility for passing this hasty mess. Someone needs to explain to the Republicans that if they cannot make good economic decisions, taxpayers have nowhere else to turn. After passing $2.7 trillion of legislation, mounds of free cash went to many people and companies that don't need it and missed many who do.

title: Shouldn't Negligent Cities Make the Looted Whole?
summary: Shouldn't those cities whose police departments failed to protect their businesses from destruction be liable?. Regarding your editorial "Who the Looting Ruins" (June 5): Shouldn't those cities whose police departments failed to protect local businesses from destruction organize, publicly, privately or both, to fund the full losses and recovery of the businesses they failed to defend? Call it "reparations for right now."

title: New York Lawmakers Pass Bills to Change Police Practices
summary: Measures include criminalizing use of chokeholds and repealing a 40-year-old statute that shields police disciplinary records. ALBANY, N.Y.-New York state lawmakers began acting Monday on a package of bills in response to continuing protests over police violence, including a measure that will make officer disciplinary records more transparent.

title: Brazil Changes Coronavirus Data Reporting
summary: President Jair Bolsonaro's administration plans to revise death toll for one of the world's worst outbreaks. SÃO PAULO-The Brazilian government is revamping how it calculates and releases data on coronavirus infections and deaths, sparking criticism that President Jair Bolsonaro is trying to hide the true extent of a pandemic that has killed more than 35,000 people.

title: New Strategies in Combating Obesity
summary: Obesity researchers are learning a lot about what works best in helping people lose weight. Perhaps most important: doctor training. In the Covid-19 pandemic, people with obesity are at higher risk for severe illness and death-adding new urgency to efforts to rethink the way doctors treat what has long been a public-health problem.

title: New York City to Expand Bus-Only Corridors
summary: Some 16.5 miles of bus lanes to be added to Manhattan, the Bronx, Queens and Staten Island, and 3.5 miles of busways. Parts of Manhattan's Fifth Avenue and sections of other major streets in New York City soon will become bus-only corridors to increase transit service, alleviate overcrowding and combat the spread of the new coronavirus, Mayor Bill de Blasio said Monday.

title: Fed Makes Terms More Favorable for Main Street Lending Program
summary: Central bank reduces minimum and raises maximum loan limits in effort to reach more small and midsize businesses. The Federal Reserve said Monday it will make terms more favorable for its incipient program to extend loans to small and midsize businesses amid public worries that the novel effort to blunt the coronavirus-driven shock might produce underwhelming results.

title: As Countries Reopen, Many Avoid a Second Wave of Covid-19 Cases-So Far
summary: Successes at limiting new infections in Europe and Asia suggest ways to hold the pandemic in check. Europe and Asia have so far avoided a significant resurgence of Covid-19 cases even though most countries have emerged from lockdown and restarted chunks of their economies, a possible sign the coronavirus pandemic can be held in check by less stringent means.

title: She's Confronting Cancer in the Middle of the Pandemic
summary: How one woman has managed surgery, radiation, chemotherapy and other treatments as coronavirus spiked. While the rest of the country watched news of the new coronavirus spreading across the country sheltered in place at home, Shahonna Anderson watched in her hospital room at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York City, the pandemic's epicenter.

title: China Steps Up Moves to Influence Diaspora Communities
summary: Countering the effort requires heightened vigilance by democratic countries, new report says. WASHINGTON-China is making fresh efforts to influence Chinese communities around the world to advance Beijing's interests, requiring heightened vigilance from democratic countries, a new study says.

title: U.K. Regulator Ends Tesco Probe, Finds No Signs of Misconduct
summary: Investigation of Tesco's accountants was spurred by company overstating profit forecast in 2014. The U.K. Financial Reporting Council closed its final investigation into Tesco PLC's earnings statements, concluding that it couldn't find evidence of misconduct among accountants.

title: Boeing Stock Soars as U.S. Reopens
summary: Shares have risen 58% so far this month amid investor optimism. Boeing Co. shares have skyrocketed 58% so far this month as the aircraft maker rides a wave of investor optimism on the reopening of the U.S. economy and a revival in air travel.

title: U.S. Prosecutors Ask U.K. for Help With Prince Andrew's Testimony in Epstein Case
summary: Advisers to the British royal say he isn't a target of probe and has offered assistance at least three times. LONDON-Advisers to Britain's Prince Andrew denied Monday that he was refusing to cooperate with a U.S. Justice Department probe into disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein, after U.S. prosecutors made a rare request through a treaty with Britain to secure testimony from the prince.

title: 'RTJ4' by Run the Jewels: Politics and Prose
summary: Lyrics drenched in advocacy meet powerful delivery in the hip-hop duo's charged, of-the-moment new album..

title: In the Feud Between Two of U.K.'s Richest Men, Family Members Say They Bugged Uncle
summary: In Barclay v. Barclay, illustrious family splits over sale of London's Ritz hotel. LONDON-Several members of Britain's billionaire Barclay family admitted to bugging their uncle and cousin, in a court case related to the sale of London's Ritz Hotel that has split the secretive clan.

title: 3M Says Merchant Sold Masks on Amazon at 18 Times List Price
summary: The seller charged customers over $350,000 in total, 3M and Amazon said.

title: FBI Wants Audit Firm to Review How It Makes FISA Wiretap Requests
summary: Move follows report faulting surveillance applications of former Trump campaign adviser Carter Page in probe of Russian election interference. The FBI is looking for an audit firm to review its procedures for making foreign intelligence surveillance requests, as the agency continues to grapple with fallout from the errors in its pursuit of a wiretap of former Trump campaign adviser Carter Page.

title: Bank of America Eases Sales Targets for Merrill Advisers During Pandemic
summary: The bank said it would pare back some of the thresholds affecting advisers' pay. Bank of America Corp. has lowered some sales targets imposed on Merrill Lynch financial advisers who have struggled to grow their businesses, acknowledging the continuing impact the coronavirus pandemic has had on its wealth-management unit.

title: New York City Reopens After Lockdown
summary: Construction, agriculture, manufacturing and wholesale trade sites resume operating; retail stores can offer curbside and in-store pickup. As the nation's largest city began reopening Monday after more than two months of lockdown, New Yorkers expressed trepidation, relief and optimism about this first step toward getting back to business.

title: South Korean Court Denies Arrest Warrant for Samsung's Lee Jae-Yong
summary: Prosecutors had accused Lee of accounting fraud tied to 2015 merger between two Samsung affiliates. Samsung 's de facto leader, Lee Jae-yong, avoided a second stint in jail when a Seoul district court judge rejected South Korean prosecutors' request to arrest the business tycoon for financial fraud in a 2015 intra-conglomerate merger.

title: Amazon Doesn't Need No Satisfaction
summary: Survey finds a drop in customer satisfaction for e-commerce giant even as sales soar. More people are spending more money than ever on Amazon.com , but fewer seem happy about it.

title: Beijing Has a New Diagnosis of Hong Kong's Ills: Opposition to Communist Rule
summary: New view on unrest departs from past statements that cited economic disparities and social tensions. HONG KONG-China's leadership believes its main challenge in Hong Kong is a political struggle against forces trying to subvert Communist Party rule, a senior Chinese official said Monday, marking a shift in Beijing's official diagnosis of unrest in the city.

title: Coronavirus Aid Distribution Methods Still Disfavor Hospitals Most in Need
summary: Disbursement draws renewed scrutiny after some funds are returned by hospitals that didn't need it or were closed. The Trump administration's distribution of about $175 billion in federal aid to health-care providers has channeled more of that money to profitable hospitals and less to struggling facilities that most need the support amid the coronavirus pandemic, drawing renewed scrutiny and criticism by lawmakers and industry groups.

title: Videogame Technology Could Bring Biofeedback Therapy to the Living Room
summary: The immersive qualities of virtual-reality gaming are making effective biofeedback treatment of anxiety and other conditions more affordable and accessible. For decades, use of biofeedback to help sufferers of anxiety, among other psychological conditions, has largely been limited to clinical settings with expensive-and somewhat tedious-medical equipment. Now, with an assist from developers of virtual-reality games, effective therapeutic biofeedback is becoming more affordable, accessible and engaging.

title: How Much Do You Know About Medical Innovation? Take Our Quiz
summary: The return of leeches, a view of viruses, and more in this Wall Street Journal quiz. Necessity it has been said, is the mother of invention. Nowhere is this truer than in health care, where the perpetual search for new treatments is most evident today in the scramble for a Covid-19 vaccine.

title: Shaming Smokers Can Backfire
summary: Study shows that putting smokers down in an effort to keep them from lighting up doesn't work, a finding that some say has implications for other addictions. Can smokers be "shamed" into kicking the habit?

title: The High Cost of Emergency-Room Crowding
summary: A 10% reduction in an ER's patient volume improves outcomes significantly, the research finds.. Crowded emergency rooms have long been a problem in the U.S., but a new study gives a clearer picture of the true cost in terms of patient outcomes.

title: Car Carrier Grimaldi Waits For 'the World to Restart'
summary: Italian shipping major has half its vehicle-transport ships idled and warns of a slow recovery in automotive trade. Ocean carriers that haul cars around the world have idled nearly a third of fleets in the sector as operators try to withstand a downturn in automotive demand that has deepened during coronavirus-driven lockdowns.

title: A New Approach to Dealing With Myopia in Kids
summary: The idea is to treat nearsightedness in children, rather than just correcting it. As the number of people with myopia accelerates, an effort is under way to treat nearsightedness in children-rather than simply correct it with glasses and contact lenses.

title: Nasdaq Overtakes NYSE in Coronavirus-Era IPOs
summary: Pandemic curtails activity, reins in celebrations of corporate debuts on NYSE's historic trading floor. Nasdaq Inc. has edged past the New York Stock Exchange in initial public offerings this year as the coronavirus pandemic has curtailed activity and reined in celebrations of corporate debuts on the NYSE's historic trading floor.

title: Cleveland Is a House-Flipping Hot Spot, and Covid Adds Fuel
summary: Resume Subscription. CLEVELAND-Economic upheaval has investors hunting for cheap houses. Many are finding them on the shores of Lake Erie.

title: Violence Threatens Black Lives
summary: I am not oppressed. I am free. African-Americans need real policy reforms, not racial antagonism.. Washington

title: Don't Cut Off Unemployment Benefits Now
summary: The economy is still at risk. Here are two options for repurposing the additional $600 benefit.. As the House and Senate begin to formulate the next emergency fiscal package, a debate is brewing over what to do about the more-generous unemployment benefits included in the Cares Act-especially the $600 addition to everyone's weekly benefits. Congress needs to debate this now because the provisions are scheduled to expire at the end of July.

title: When Work From Home Means Working From an RV
summary: Coronavirus pandemic is prompting consumers to look at recreational vehicles as mobile offices, motor-home maker Thor Industries says. A growing number of first-time buyers are boosting RV maker Thor Industries Inc. during the coronavirus pandemic, the company said Monday, as consumers look to use recreational vehicles for socially distant travel and as mobile offices.

title: Relief Spreads to Risky European Bank Bonds
summary: Yields on junior bank debt have fallen almost back to precrisis levels. European bank bonds have rallied over the past few weeks, escaping crisis territory thanks to the easing of coronavirus lockdowns and the proposed launch of a European Union-wide recovery fund.

title: Volkswagen CEO Gives Up Dual Role as Chief of Namesake Brand
summary: Herbert Diess steps down as head of VW brand in management shake-up following execution stumbles at German auto maker. BERLIN- Volkswagen AG is reshuffling the management of its namesake VW brand in a response to the botched launch of the latest Golf, the company's top-selling model, and persistent troubles readying the new all-electric ID-3 set to go on sale this summer.

title: Pandemic Unwinds Asia's Gains in Getting Poor to School
summary: Coronavirus measures are reversing hard-won gains in education in developing countries. Yen Corpuz's eight young siblings and cousins who share a shanty in one the poorest slums of Manila were all enrolled in schools at the start of this year. This fall, none of them plan to go back.

title: You've Shared Your Netflix Password With Your Entire Family. Now You Can't Watch Netflix.
summary: Resume Subscription. Satele Brewer had finished an exhausting day of work when he tried to log in to the Netflix account he shares with his family. A message popped up on his screen telling him he couldn't watch "Breaking Bad" because too many people were using the account at one time.

title: Why the Extremist 'Boogaloo Boys' Wear Hawaiian Shirts
summary: Aloha shirts have become a disconcerting signature for members of a gun-toting, anti-government faction. IN THE PAST COUPLE of weeks, following the killing of George Floyd, curiously dressed counter protesters have attended scattered demonstrations across the U.S. Often armed and disconcertingly garbed in "Magnum P.I."-style floral Hawaiian shirts, these men and women have gathered on the fringes of gatherings and marches in states including Texas, Georgia and Pennsylvania.

title: California Resources Is Preparing Near-Term Bankruptcy Filing
summary: Oil driller could seek chapter 11 protection as soon as next week to restructure about $5 billion of debt. Oil company California Resources Corp. skipped an interest payment to lenders and could file for bankruptcy as soon as next week, people familiar with the matter said.

title: Nestlé to Sell Buitoni Pasta Brand's North American Business
summary: Nestlé is selling pasta brand's North American business to consumer-focused private-equity firm Brynwood Partners after more than 30 years of ownership. Nestlé SA is selling the North American business of its Buitoni pasta brand to a private-equity firm as the Swiss consumer-goods giant focuses on higher performing frozen brands like Hot Pockets, Stouffer's and Lean Cuisine.

title: Expert Advice for a Safe Road Trip
summary: Hitting the highways this summer? Here are precautions drivers should take to keep themselves and passengers safe as states and cities reopen.. As vacationers hit the road this summer, they should exercise caution to stay safe from Covid-19. With cities and states in various stages of reopening, guidance about the virus is changing quickly. Also, road-trippers may encounter traffic or roads blocked off due to social-justice protests. We asked experts for advice.

title: Lawsuit Accusing Contractors of Paying Protection Money to Taliban Is Expanded
summary: U.S. contractors added to complaint by families of more than two hundred U.S. personnel wounded, killed in Afghanistan. WASHINGTON-Families of American soldiers and personnel wounded or killed in Afghanistan have accused two U.S. contractors of paying protection money to the Taliban, expanding a lawsuit filed earlier.

title: Oil Falters as Libyan, U.S. Production Threatens to Mute OPEC Cuts
summary: Higher production from Libya and the U.S. offset moves to curb global energy supply and bolster prices while demand recovers. Oil prices wobbled after a deal by OPEC and its allies to extend production cuts was offset by the prospect of increased output from Libya and U.S. shale producers.

title: BP to Cut 14% of Global Workforce as Drop in Oil Price Bites
summary: The British energy giant plans to cut almost 10,000 mostly office-based jobs as the coronavirus pandemic hits demand. BP PLC is cutting thousands of jobs, accelerating existing plans to reshape the company after the coronavirus pandemic's crushing impact on oil prices.

title: Behind HSBC's Rare Foray Into Politics Over Hong Kong
summary: Global lender that relies heavily on the city for profits backed China's controversial proposed security law. For a century and a half, HSBC Holdings PLC steered a neutral course through the messy geopolitics of east versus west. Now a public signal of the bank's support for China over the future of Hong Kong has set off a storm of criticism.

title: The NBA Player Whose Family Marched With MLK
summary: Indiana Pacers guard Malcolm Brogdon's grandfather was a leader in the civil-rights movement. Now he's finding his own voice.. Malcolm Brogdon had a megaphone in his hand and family history on his mind.

title: World Bank Sees 5.2% Decline in Global Economy in 2020 From Coronavirus
summary: The international lender says that never before have so many countries entered a recession at once. The global economy is expected to shrink by about 5.2% in 2020 as a result of the coronavirus pandemic, making it one of the four most severe downturns in 150 years, the World Bank said Monday.

title: Pandemic Upends Putin's Plans to Raise Russia's Dwindling Birthrate
summary: Resume Subscription. MOSCOW-Starting a family was a priority for Olga Luchitskaya and Yaroslav Balagansky when they married five years ago. Their first attempt ended in a miscarriage, and now the coronavirus pandemic is making them rethink their plans.

title: Trump Knocks Fellow Bad Airline Investor Buffett
summary: The president pointed out Berkshire Hathaway's error this year in dumping airlines before they surged, but his own record in the air leaves much to be desired. Warren Buffett has been forced to develop a thick skin managing people's money. While the overall results have made him a legend, critics have been quick to note his errors. The latest: the president of the U.S.

title: The NFL Talks the Talk. Will It Walk the Walk?
summary: A contrite statement from league commissioner Roger Goodell signals the league is ready to listen. Can it handle the heat?. What did the Hall of Fame wide receiver Terrell Owens say a bunch of years ago when he joined the Dallas Cowboys?

title: Federal Budget Deficit Nears $2 Trillion
summary: U.S. budget gap more than doubled in May as the pandemic undercut federal revenue and triggered spending increases. WASHINGTON-The U.S. budget gap more than doubled in May, pushing the deficit for the fiscal year to near $2 trillion, as federal revenues plunged and government spending soared to help combat the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Consumers 'More Optimistic' About Economy's Future in May, New York Fed Says
summary: Americans are growing more upbeat about what lies ahead for the economy, even as they brace for what they see as a rise in inflationary pressure. Americans are growing more upbeat about what lies ahead for the economy, even as they brace for what they see as a rise in inflationary pressure, a new report from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said Monday.

title: Minority Players Form Alliance to 'Eradicate Racism' in Hockey
summary: The Hockey Diversity Alliance, led by Akim Aliu and Evander Kane, says it wants to confront hockey's culture of intolerance and promote diversity. A group of prominent, minority hockey players has teamed up to fight racism in hockey-a sport that was already amid a reckoning about its predominantly white demographics before national protests centered on racism.

title: Crises Lay Bare a Goodwill Deficit in America
summary: This spring's discontents have heightened a partisan divide reflecting a broad intolerance of opposing views. The brutal shocks hitting America this spring have opened up a variety of financial deficits. Perhaps more important, though, they have revealed a more pervasive underlying condition: a goodwill deficit.

title: How the First Popular Movie Ever to Stream Online Was Made
summary: A 'Party Girl' oral history: Wild tales behind the makings of the '90s cult classic starring Parker Posey-25 years after it first beamed across the Web.. So many aspects of the 1995 film Party Girl have the makings of a fairytale: a wise godmother, handsome strangers from far-away lands, dazzling outfits, jubilant soirées. In her breakout role, actress Parker Posey plays a young woman who works as a librarian during the day and hits downtown Manhattan dance floors packed with glamorous drag queens at night. Even its plot feels otherworldly in its idealism and simplicity.

title: Pinterest Juggles Requests for Late Payments From Advertisers
summary: CFO of image-sharing platform says more businesses want payment extensions. The chief financial officer of Pinterest Inc. is working to keep revenue flowing without alienating cash-strapped advertisers that use its online image-sharing platform.

title: Prof. Scott Galloway Wants to Be 'the Most Influential Thought Leader in the History of Business'
summary: The NYU Stern professor launches a TV show from his backyard: 'People would not have accepted Chris Cuomo broadcasting from his bad basement. And now they'll accept it.'. In our series My Monday Morning, self-motivated people tell WSJ. how they start off the week.

title: Fed Debates Yield Caps; Jobs Surprise Highlights Fed's Forecasting Challenge; Investors Back ECB to Avert Italy Debt Crisis
summary: Resume Subscription. Good day. Fed officials are considering capping Treasury yields for the first time since 1951 to signal their commitment to keeping interest rates low. Policy makers are studying the recent experience of Australia's central bank, which in March set a target of 0.25% for the country's three-year bond yield, Nick Timiraos reports. Meanwhile, Friday's surprisingly strong U.S. jobs data shows how hard it is to make forecasts in these uncharted economic waters, underscoring a challenge for the Fed as it prepares its own projections. And investors are betting that aggressive action from the European Central Bank will help Italy avert a debt crisis.

title: This South Korean City Can't Quit Coronavirus Social Distancing
summary: Resume Subscription. DAEGU, South Korea-More than three months after Covid-19 cases peaked here, local transmissions have all but disappeared from South Korea's hardest-hit city. Still, Daegu looks far from relaxed.

title: Kennedy-Markey Senate Battle Heats Up in Massachusetts
summary: The campaigns have emerged after weeks of coronavirus lockdown, meeting for a debate last week and with another planned for Monday. A young challenger calling for generational change versus an older incumbent is hardly a unique dynamic in modern Democratic politics. But in Massachusetts, the former is the scion of the state's most powerful political dynasty, and the veteran has the backing of liberals known for taking on the establishment, such as Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D., N.Y.).

title: Chimerica Isn't Dead, but the Pandemic Wounded It
summary: The 30% collapse in foreign investment globally expected this year offers an unparalleled opportunity for a shift in the deep commercial linkages between the U.S. and China. Chimerica, the intertwined manufacturing colossus that boomed across the Pacific from the early 1990s, looked far past its prime even before the pandemic. The effect of pandemic-related shortages will deal another serious wound to the framework.

title: Coronavirus Downdraft Has Airports Scaling Back Renovation Plans
summary: San Francisco, Orlando and Heathrow delay or reduce construction projects; 'it simply wasn't required that we do it right now'. As the coronavirus pandemic stifles air travel, major airports around the world are rethinking plans to spend billions of dollars on new terminals, runways and hotels that could sit empty if demand doesn't return.

title: Cristobal Weakens to Tropical Depression After Louisiana Landfall
summary: Storm stirs up dangerous weather farther east, including a tornado in Florida. NEW ORLEANS-Cristobal weakened to a tropical depression Monday morning, after crashing ashore as a lopsided tropical storm a day prior in Louisiana and ginned up dangerous weather farther east, sending waves crashing over Mississippi beaches, swamping parts of an Alabama island town and spawning a tornado in Florida.

title: Movie Theaters Face Their Biggest Summer Thriller Yet
summary: Cinemark and other theater chains are banking heavily on 'Tenet' to bring back audiences after reopenings. Can movie theaters survive the pandemic? A Texas-based chain and a British-born director might help answer that question.

title: Companies Find New Perks for the Remote Worker
summary: New extras aim to de-stress workers with meditation apps and virtual yoga and gym workouts. And snacks!. As many companies enter a third month of lockdown with no clear end in sight, employers are toying with new perks that might address some of the struggles remote workers are facing on their own.

title: Company Liquidity Warnings Have a Silver Lining
summary: This year will bring a big increase in "going concern" notices in financial statements, but investors shouldn't despair. Investors should brace for a wave of ominous-sounding liquidity warnings in companies' financial results. They may also learn to love them.

title: Lone Wolves, Self-Styled Anarchists: The Disparate Actors Accused of Protest Violence
summary: Officials warn extremists groups have infiltrated some George Floyd protests; criminal charges, investigations reveal still-hazy picture. As flares of violence and destruction have disrupted largely peaceful demonstrations against police brutality over the past two weeks, federal and state officials have warned that members of extremist groups are at work behind the scenes.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: As Covid-19 Closes Summer Camps, Small Towns Brace for Impact
summary: Cancellation of seasonal gatherings including sleep-away camps, festivals, sports tournaments and concerts hurts local businesses. Camp counselors and staff usually start rolling into Hancock, N.Y., in early June, buying buckets of paint and hammers and nails, movie tickets, pizzas and vodka from local businesses.

title: Protests Fuel Moves to Shift Funding From Police
summary: Largest demonstrations remained mostly peaceful over weekend; Trump tells National Guard to begin D.C. pullout and New York ends curfew. The largest protests sparked by the killing of George Floyd remained mostly peaceful across the U.S. this weekend, as emboldened organizers said they didn't plan to stop rallying until they saw concrete changes in police policy.

title: 'Billions' Recap, Season 5, Episode 6: Now, Axe is Facing Charges of Art Fraud
summary: From a weird banking scheme that Axe just won't let go of to starting a makeshift museum, what's real and what's not on the latest episode.. Bobby Axelrod still doesn't have his bank, but he does have a museum.

title: Coronavirus Good News
summary: Science and medical trial and error are keeping more patients alive.. Good news: A new study finds that the novel coronavirus has become less lethal over the past few months. While there's no evidence that mutations are making the virus less deadly, treatments have improved enormously as scientists have learned more.

title: U.S.-Stock Funds Rallied 6.3% in May
summary: A second month of strong advances, as coronavirus lockdowns have been lifted, has made the year-to-date declines much more tolerable. The stock market is proving again that it is all about the anticipation of what's ahead, not the present or past.

title: Investors Flock to Cash. Here's What They Need to Know.
summary: Cash makes investors feel safer, but they should understand the cost. Big-name investors from Warren Buffett to Leon Cooperman said they went to cash as the fastest bear market in history crushed financial markets in the first quarter. Data from the first quarter suggests many individual investors went to cash as well.

title: Small 'Value' Stocks Are Down but Not Out
summary: After a horrendous first quarter, small-cap shares with low P/Es could be reviving. Small-capitalization "value" stocks have been among the market's worst performers this year. But the sector might be well positioned to outperform the broad market when the economy begins to recover from Covid-19 lockdowns, some analysts say.

title: Why People Misunderstand Dividends, and the Damage This Does
summary: A London Business School professor writes that brokerage firms and corporations could help us fix our irrational, inflexible way of thinking about dividends. Over the past year, voices across the corporate and political spectrum have argued that companies are beholden to all stakeholders, not just shareholders. And indeed, many companies are recognizing these responsibilities in the current pandemic, with several paying furloughed workers and donating products. Investors have largely supported those efforts.

title: How Preferred Shares Have Performed Over the Past Decade
summary: An analysis shows they have underperformed stocks while just keeping up with bonds. Yet, they have significantly more volatility than bonds.. Investors don't understand preferred stock.

title: Videogame ETFs Cashed In on Lockdowns, but Can They Keep Going?
summary: Interactive entertainment is hot; as gaming and esports take off, spectators tune in to eNascar. As global lockdowns fueled demand for in-home entertainment, exchange-traded funds that focus on videogames reaped the rewards. This could accelerate longer-term trends, though there may be pitfalls ahead.

title: How Overconfident Investors Influence Share Prices
summary: Many investors simply refuse to believe that their competition in the market might know more than they do, say two professors. Momentum investing-buying stocks that have recently performed well, in the hopes that they will continue to outperform-has proved its potential as a profitable strategy. But what makes it work? Why do stocks continue to rise without fresh information to fuel their ascent?

title: Wall Street Has No Consensus
summary: Forecasts from analysts about the market and economy are ranging from financial Armageddon to a swift second-half recovery. Judging by their collective forecasts, Wall Street professionals seem confused over where the market and the economy are headed. The estimates of third-quarter economic growth and year-end stock-index levels vary widely compared with just a few weeks ago.

title: Will Stocks Trail Bonds Over the Next Decade?
summary: It would startle investors, but a new analysis suggests there is a decent chance that will happen. The conventional wisdom among investors hasn't changed for years: Stocks beat bonds in the long run.

title: What Is the Dollar's 'Smile'?
summary: The theory says the U.S. currency tends to increase in value against other currencies when the U.S. economy is either extremely weak or strong. Investors sometimes talk about the "smile" of the U.S. dollar. What does it mean?

title: New York Times Editorial-Page Editor James Bennet Resigns
summary: Resignation comes amid controversy over recent op-ed by Sen. Tom Cotton; Deputy Kathleen Kingsbury to take over as acting editorial page editor. The New York Times editorial page chief resigned, becoming the second prominent U.S. newspaper editor to lose his job over decisions related to coverage of civil unrest following the killing of George Floyd.
